ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This is a great, important class to take, even as an undergraduate. You will learn how to read books thoroughly and quickly, how to engage and critique material, and how to write well. It's a necessary survey-type course that assesses a lot that is missing from the undergraduate curriculum.

I would definitely recommend this class to another student largely for the strengths I've listed above. In short, not only was the class intellectually fulfilling, it was also a great survey of different models for becoming a historian.Also, the class had students from a wide variety of backgrounds (international relations, geography, medicine, forestry, among others) which made the discussion rich and widely-applicable. With the success of this semester, I imagine that diversity in the class will continue.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Again, I've outlined the ways in which the course was a study of the sociology of the academy and how helpful this is for an incoming grad student.Because my research is in the history of medicine, content-wise (i.e. regarding historical "facts") this course was not as useful. However on a theoretical and conceptual level the course has been very useful. The main contribution to my future research is a deeper understanding of historiographical issues surrounding the public. Though this is quite specific to my research, given the structure of the course - where you are allowed to write on any topic discussed in the class for your final paper - and the depth of discussion I imagine that most students will be able to find a historiographical problem that they find useful.

The course really asked students to consider the history of science as a field, asking us what defines the discipline and its possible future directions. This is a useful way to conceptualize the course, and perhaps we can also ask about the past of the field as well. The course can provide both a sense of where we are coming from, what the field looks like now, and where we might take it in the future.
